phoenix

Class image

  • java.lang.Object
    • phoenix.image

  • public final class image
extends java.lang.Object
    API Generated: Tue May 17 06:47:42 EDT 2016
    API Source: ImageAPI
    Set of Image APIs for performing transformations on images. Typically in all cases, transformed images will be cached to the filesystem, if at all possible, so that repeat calls to the same image transformation will simply reuse the cached image file.

    Transformations are basically json (javascript object notation) structures that define one or more transformations. The followsing transformations exist
    • {name: scale, width: 150, height: -1}
    • {name: reflection}
    • {name: reflection, alphaStart:0, alphaEnd:1.0}
    • {name: just_reflection, alphaStart:0, alphaEnd:1.0}
    • {name: perspective, scalex:10, shifty:20}
    • {name: gradient, width: 500, height: 600, opacityStart:0, opacityEnd:1}
    • {name: rotate, theta: .90}
    • {name: shadow, size: 10, opacity: .8, color: 0xff00ff}
    • {name: opacity, opacity: .8}
    • {name: overlay, image: 'src/test/images/test_small.jpg', opacity:0.5, x:100, y:100}
    • {name: rounded, arcSize:10}
    • {name: dummy}

    Because a transformation is a json structure, you can pass in an array of transformations as the transformation string. ie, [{name: scale, width: 100}, {name: reflection}]. If you pass in a json array as the transformation, then each transformation will be applied to the buffer and then the end result will be cached to the filesystem.

    A transform can also accept an 'id' field as well. If an 'id' is present, then that transform will automatically be registered and can then be accessed by that id. ie, if you used the following transform {name:scale, height: 100, id: poster_thumb}, then later you simply reference that transform using {id:poster_thumb}. This is useful if you want to register transforms for specific purposes and then simply refer to them by id later in your stv code.

    When creating a transformation, you can pass 'tag'. A tag is simply a "grouping" which ends up being a directory in the image cache. Using a tag can be useful if you want to group together a bunch of transformations for a given purpose. You can then quickly identify them in their cached folder, and easily remove the directory if you want to purge the cache.

      • LoadImages

        public static void LoadImages(java.lang.Object imageArr)
        Deprecated. UI Should try to load thier own images.
        Given an array of images, Call Sage's LoadImage on them. This will force sage to load them into it's cache.

        This api call has been depecrated, since the UI should try to load their own images. There is the potential with this API to overload the UI memory with too many images.

        Parameters:
        imageArray - Array or List of images

      • CreateImages

        public static void CreateImages(java.lang.String imageTag,
                                java.lang.Object imageArr,
                                java.lang.String jsonTransform,
                                boolean overwriteImages)
        Given an Array/List of images, apply the same transformation to image element. The operation happens in a background thread.
        Parameters:
        imageTag - common tag/name to apply to each transformation
        imageArr - image array
        jsonTransform - json transform
        overwriteImages - if true, it will overwrite previously cached images

      • CreateImage

        public static java.lang.Object CreateImage(java.lang.String id,
                                           java.lang.String tag,
                                           java.lang.Object image,
                                           java.lang.String transform,
                                           boolean overwrite)
        Creates a new Image by applying the given transform. The resulting image will be cached and can get retrieved by using GetImage(id, tag).

        If overwrite is set to false, then a cached version of the image will be used. If a cached version does not exist, then it will created and cached.

        id and tag are meant to be used together to uniquely identify a cached instance. ie, the id may be image filename, while the tag may represent the "type" of transformation that is applied. The image tag is combined with the image id to make the cached entry unique.

        The transform is the transform, or series of transforms that you want to apply to an image using javascript notation (json). ie, {name: scale, width: 100, height: 200}

        When a tag is provided, the image cache will put all images from the same tag in the same directory. This makes for easy housecleaning. For example, if you use a tag, "poster_small" for all your poster thumbnails, then you can easily remove all the poster thumbnails, by removing the poster_small dir from the image cache.

        Parameters:
        id - image id (ie, filename, virtual filename, or some unique id)
        tag - imae tag (ie, image group, poster, poster_small, background, etc) used with the image id to make the id + tag uqique
        image - image to transform
        transform - json transform to apply
        overwrite - true if you want to overwrite an existing cached instance
        Returns:
        Sage image

      • CreateImageAsFile

        public static java.io.File CreateImageAsFile(java.lang.String id,
                                             java.lang.String tag,
                                             java.lang.Object image,
                                             java.lang.String transform,
                                             boolean overwrite)
        Same as CreateImage except that the returned image will be a File.
        Parameters:
        id - image id (ie, filename, virtual filename, or some unique id)
        tag - imae tag (ie, image group, poster, poster_small, background, etc) used with the image id to make the id + tag uqique
        image - image to transform
        transform - json transform to apply
        overwrite - true if you want to overwrite an existing cached instance
        Returns:
        Transformed Image File, or NULL.

      • GetImage

        public static java.lang.Object GetImage(java.lang.Object image,
                                        java.lang.String tag)
        Gets a previously generated/cached transformation for the given image object with the specified tag.

        For example, if a bunch of images were previously created using a tag of "poster_thumb" and a specific transform, then you can recall that cached image using only the image and it's tag.

        Parameters:
        image - Original image path
        tag - tag for the transform that was applied
        Returns:

      • GetImage

        public static java.lang.Object GetImage(java.lang.String id,
                                        java.lang.String tag)
        Gets an image by it's virtual id and tag. For example you could have created a cached transformation for a given image and given it a unique id and tag. You can then later recall the cached image using only the id and tag. This is sometimes useful if the original image is a sage image or a buffered image. Since there isn't a file path associated with the image, it could not normally be cached. But if you gave it an id and tag, then it can be cached and recalled.
        Parameters:
        id - virtual id that was assigned to an image
        tag - arbitrary tag/group for the image
        Returns:
        File object representint the image, or null;

      • RegisterImageTransform

        public static void RegisterImageTransform(java.lang.String transform)
        Registers a transformation that can be recalled later. The transform must contains an "id" field.
        Parameters:
        transform - json transformation script

      • RegisterImageTransform

        public static void RegisterImageTransform(java.lang.String transform,
                                          java.lang.String id)
        Registers a transformation that can be recalled later. The transform is registered using the id. This API is normally used to register a composite transformation (ie json array) since there is no way to actually name the json array using and id field.
        Parameters:
        transform - json transformation script
        id - for the transformation

      • RegisterImage

        public static void RegisterImage(java.lang.String id,
                                 java.lang.String tag,
                                 java.lang.Object image,
                                 java.lang.String transform,
                                 boolean overwrite)
        Registers a transformed image that can later be recalled using the id and tag. Register image differs from CreateImage in that RegisterImage may not apply the transformation immediately. It may queue the transformation and do it in a background thread.

        TODO: This is not implemented... so currently RegisterImage behaves like CreateImage except that it does not return the image.

        Parameters:
        id -
        tag -
        image -
        transform -
        overwrite -

      • CreateScaledImage

        public static java.lang.Object CreateScaledImage(java.lang.Object image,
                                                 int width,
                                                 int height)
        Deprecated. use CreateImage
        Returns a scaled image of the source image. If the scaled image cannot be found/created, then the original is passed back.

        If a scaled image is not located, then a scaled image is created on the fly and saved, so that the next call will have access to the scaled image.

        Parameters:
        image - String file/url, or File, or Sage File or BufferedImage
        width - scaled width; -1 means proportional
        height - scaled height; -1 means proportional
        Returns:
